column8: \"content\": \"Key Point: US technological innovation and industrial practice made it possible for the USN to develop and maintain submarines with advanced noise-suppression technology. The USSR\\u2019s tried to answer through raw weight
column9: both in terms of size and number of boats.\\n\\nHistory\\u2019s three great submarine campaigns include the First Battle of the Atlantic
column10: the Second Battle of the Atlantic
column11: and the US Navy\\u2019s (USN) war against Japanese commerce in World War II. The contestants fought these campaigns through asymmetrical means
column12: with submarines doing battle against aircraft and surface escorts.\\n\\nBut the greatest true submarine campaign never (or only intermittently) went \\u201chot.\\u201d Waged with advanced
column13: streamlined submarines
column14: hunting each other from the polar ice cap to the Eastern seaboard
column15: the Cold War undersea \\u201cgame\\u201d lasted for over three decades. In case of real war
column16: these submarines would safeguard (or destroy) NATO\\u2019s trans-Atlantic lifeline
column17: and would protect (or sink) much of the nuclear deterrent of America
column18: Russia
column19: Britain
column20: and France.\\n\\nSo what were the best submarines of the Cold War era? For the purposes of this list
column21: we\\u2019re excluding ballistic missiles submarines or boomers
column22: which have an entirely different mission from attack boats
column23: built for different requirements. Instead
column24: this list will focus on submarines optimized for killing surface ships or other submarines. The criteria should be familiar from previous lists; to what extent did the vessels perform its strategic mission at a price that its nation could afford?\\n\\nCost: Submarines compete with other providers of national security. If they break the bank
column25: they risk crowding out the other capabilities that a nation requires for its defense.\\n\\nReliability: When submarines have accidents
column26: the results can be catastrophic. And showing up is half the battle; boats stuck in port can\\u2019t fulfill national objectives.\\n\\nEffectiveness: Could the submarine do the job? How did it stack up against its contemporaries?\\n\\nLarge
column27: fast
column28: and quiet
column29: the Permit class set that standard for American and British submarines for the rest of the Cold War. Developed with a series of innovations that set them apart from their predecessors
column30: the Skipjack class
column31: the Permits immediately became state of the undersea art. These innovations included powerful bow sonar
column32: a streamlined
column33: deep-dive capable hull
column34: and advanced quieting technology. Among the first submarines conceived an optimized for an anti-submarine mission
column35: the Permits could threaten not only the Soviet deterrent
column36: but also the Russian capacity for disrupting the trans-Atlantic lifeline.\\n\\nThe first of fourteen Permits entered service in 1961
column37: the last in 1968. Most of the boats served through the end of the Cold War. Displacing 4200 tons
column38: the Permits could make 28 knots
column39: and could fire both advanced torpedoes and Harpoon anti-ship missiles.\\n\\nThe lead ship of the Permit class was Thresher
column40: commissioned in 1961. On April 10
column42: she was lost with all hands while conducting a diving test. The tragic loss of Thresher
column43: which imploded after a still-disputed systems failure
column44: overshadowed the long careers of the rest of the class. However
column45: that loss was critical to developing the safety standards that would prevent future accidents. The loss of Thresher
column46: in a very important sense
column47: led to the long history of safety success in the USN\\u2019s submarine fleet.\\n\\nThe United States and the Soviet Union were the main players in the Cold War submarine campaign
column48: but were hardly the only entrants. The Royal Navy
column49: initially with some US assistance
column50: developed a series of lethal nuclear submarine designs
column51: eventually making a more than creditable contribution to NATO\\u2019s undersea posture. One submarine
column53: remains the only nuclear submarine to have destroyed an enemy ship in anger.\\n\\nFollowing up on the Churchill class
column54: the Swiftsures were of innovative design
column55: both in terms of hull technology and propulsion. They were the first full class of submarines to employ pump jet technology
column56: which made propulsion more efficient while reducing noise. The enlarged but simplified hull redistributed machinery allowed a much deeper diving depth than previous Royal Navy subs.\\n\\nDisplacing 5000 tons submerged
column57: the Swiftsures could make some 30 knots submerged. They carried standard torpedoes
column58: as well as Harpoon and (in some boats) Tomahawk cruise missiles. The six Swiftsures entered service between 1973 and 1981
column59: with the last decommissioning in 2010.\\n\\nThe Swiftsures had their problems
column60: including a series of bizarre accidental collisions
column61: some structural failures
column62: and some minor reactor troubles. Nevertheless
column63: they served the Royal Navy very effectively against the Soviets
column64: and would have won victories in the Falklands if the politics had played out differently.\\n\\nNot every navy can afford an advanced nuclear attack submarine. Nevertheless
column65: submarines solve strategic problems
column66: and not every great submarine needs to be a Porsche. The German Type 209
column67: first built in 1971
column68: served as the strategic answer for a great many navies in the Cold War
column69: and continues to serve today.\\n\\nFor obvious reasons
column70: German submarine development stalled at the end of World War II. Although the Type XXI set the standard for post-war boats
column71: legal restrictions prevented both East and West Germany from building any submarines in the first decade of the Cold War. After a series of designs that ran from non-to-moderately successful
column72: HDW developed the Type 209 class for export.\\n\\nA diesel-electric
column73: the Type 209 displaces between 1200 and 1800 tons (depending on variant)
column74: and can make 23 knots submerged. It can launch both torpedoes and anti-ship weapons
column75: such as the Harpoon. The basic hull design has proven remarkably flexible
column76: spawning a series of variants specialized for different tasks. The Type 209 gives small navies a viable anti-submarine option
column77: as well as the capacity to threaten the surface forces of much larger
column78: more powerful fleets.\\n\\nSince 1971
column79: 61 Type 209s have entered service with thirteen navies. 59 of those boats remain in service
column80: with two more scheduled for delivery to Egypt in 2016. The ability of the Type 209 to remain in service in so many different fleets
column81: often in widely varying maintenance conditions
column82: attests to the robust nature of the initial design.\\n\\nThe Oscars were the apogee of the Soviet cruise missile submarine
column83: a type that began with the Echo and continued with the Charlie. The first Oscars entered service in 1981
column84: and immediately presented a serious challenge for Western naval planners. Designed specifically for anti-shipping attacks
column85: these subs could strike NATO carrier groups with P-700 Granit missiles from a range of up to 300 miles. This widened the area that American anti-submarine vessels needed to patrol
column86: and meant that attacks could come from unexpected vectors. Equipped with a conventional warhead
column87: the Granit could easily cause a mission kill. With a nuclear warhead
column88: it could give a carrier battle group a very bad day.\\n\\nAnd the Oscars were huge. Displacing 16500 tons
column89: they could make 32 knots submerged. They carried 24 Granit missiles
column90: in addition to a bevy of torpedo launched weapons.\\n\\nThe United States and the United Kingdom would eventually adopt the same practice as the Russians
column91: although instead of dedicating specific sub types to cruise missile launches they would focus on converting missiles for launch from conventionally designed nuclear attack subs. Later boats in the Los Angeles class would carry dedicated cruise missile silos
column92: technically making them SSGNs instead of SSNs
column93: although the designation never changed in practice (until the conversion of four Ohio class boomers to the cruise missile mission). The real utility of cruise missiles has been land attack rather than naval attack
column94: as cruise missiles launched from US subs have proven quite effective in several recent conflicts.\\n\\nThe Soviets completed only five Oscars before the end of the Cold War
column95: and another eight after. One
column97: was lost in one of the most horrific accidents in submarine history. Several others
column98: however
column99: remain in service with the Russian Navy.\\n\\nThe United States enjoyed technology and designs advantages for most of the Cold War that allowed its submarines to operate much more quietly than their Soviet counterparts. US technological innovation and industrial practice made it possible for the USN to develop and maintain submarines with advanced noise-suppression technology. The USSR\\u2019s tried to answer through raw weight
column100: both in terms of size and number of boats.\\n\\nSoviet espionage also tried to even the score. The fruits of the Walker spy ring and the Toshiba-Konigsberg scandal spread across several classes of Soviet submarine
column101: but the Akulas benefitted most of all. The Akula\\u2019s were the first Soviet submarines to compete with American submarines on noise
column102: reportedly matching the Los Angeles class at most speeds. Displacing 8000 tons
column103: the Akulas could both outrun and outgun the American Los Angeles class
column104: making up to 35 knots and carrying a larger array of torpedoes and cruise missiles.\\n\\nSteel hulled (unlike their Sierra and Alfa predecessors)
column105: the Akulas also achieved cost-savings while improving mission capability
column106: a rare feat for a modern weapon system. Five Akulas entered service before the Cold War ended
column107: with a total of fifteen eventually entering service. Nine remain in Russian service
column108: with another on loan to the Indian Navy.\"

column8: \"content\": \"The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) chair who oversaw the implementation of Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act has admitted the mistake he and others made by creating special privileges in the marketplace that have allowed for the rise of monopoly tech firms.\\n\\nReed Hundt spoke to ProMarket about the monster he helped create when he led the FCC during the Clinton administration from 1993 to 1997. column14: and another school where it is not just about efficiency\\u2014it is also about the social impact. And it goes back and forth

column16: almost uniquely among countries

column18: from roughly the late 1970s

Section 230 has allowed these Silicon Valley monoliths to act as partisan publishers without being punitively responsible for the content on their platforms.\\n\\nSection 230 reads as follows: \\u201cNo provider or user of an interactive computer service shall be treated as the publisher or speaker of any information provided by another information content provider.\\u201d\\n\\nHundt now admits the mistake that he and other regulators made when they were responsible for crafting the law in the 1990s.\\n\\n\\u201cWe were na\\u00efve. Josh Hawley (R-MO) to force digital platforms to be neutral in how they prepare their algorithms and moderate their content.\\n\\n\\u201cWith Section 230
column38: tech companies get a sweetheart deal that no other industry enjoys: complete exemption from traditional publisher liability in exchange for providing a forum free of political censorship
column39: \\u201d Hawley said in a statement. \\u201cUnfortunately
column40: and unsurprisingly
column41: big tech has failed to hold up its end of the bargain.\\u201d\\n\\n\\u201cThere\\u2019s a growing list of evidence that shows big tech companies making editorial decisions to censor viewpoints they disagree with
column42: \\u201d Hawley added. \\u201cEven worse

column44: they must bring transparency and accountability to their editorial processes and prove that they don\\u2019t discriminate.\\u201d\\n\\nThe tech giants have become perhaps the most powerful entities in the history of mankind

column7: \"title\": \"From self-partnered to consciously uncoupled \\u2014 are you familiar with the latest celebrity lingo?\"
column8: \"content\": \"WHEN Emma Watson told Vogue a few months ago she doesn\\u2019t like the term \\u201csingle\\u201d
column9: preferring instead to call herself \\u201cself-partnered\\u201d
column10: I almost spat out my tea. And I wasn\\u2019t the only one to raise an eyebrow.\\n\\nThe revelation resulted in endless masturbation jokes on Twitter and Piers Morgan inevitably commenting: \\u201cSo she can\\u2019t get a bloke then?\\u201d\\n\\nWhile Piers was being typically irritating
column11: I do feel that we\\u2019ve reached saturation point when it comes to celebrity jargon.\\n\\nEmma certainly isn\\u2019t the first star to coin her own turn of phrase when talking about her love life. Eskimos might have 50 words for snow
column12: but A-listers have even more than that for breaking up.\\n\\nIt\\u2019s never because they can\\u2019t stand the sight of each other
column13: or because they\\u2019ve had one too many fights about why they always have to go and see his parents all the time \\u2013 celebrities are way too perfect for your bog-standard dumping. Instead

column7: \"title\": \"Trade Truce? China and America Have a Small Trade Deal\\u2014but Will It Last?\"
column8: \"content\": \"The United States and China moved Dec. 12 to soothe the sting of their trade war
column9: agreeing in principle to a so-called \\\"phase one\\\" trade deal that would ease the reciprocal tariffs that have reverberated through the world economy for almost two years. One crucial aspect of the deal is an agreement by the United States to suspend additional tariffs set to take effect Dec. 15 and
column10: crucially
column11: reduce some of the tariffs already in place on some $360 billion in Chinese goods. And thanks to the deal
column12: Washington and Beijing might finally have exited their tit-for-tat tariff escalations
column13: although clouds remain on the horizon: After all
column14: the scope of the phase one deal is narrow
column15: and the two sides will struggle to agree to a more comprehensive deal \\u2014 portending perhaps even more disruptive battles in the tech supply chain in the year to come.\\n\\nAlthough officials did not provide text of the agreement that was authorized by U.S. President Donald Trump
column16: Washington has reportedly agreed to cancel a new round of 15 percent tariffs on $160 billion worth of Chinese products \\u2014 mainly consumer goods. According to leaks of the deal's details
column17: the United States will also cut existing tariffs of 25 percent on $250 billion in Chinese products to 12.5 percent and of 15 percent on another $112 billion in goods to 7.5 percent. In return
column18: China has reportedly made an oral agreement to purchase $50 billion in U.S. agricultural products in 2020. Plus
column19: China promised to broaden access to its financial sector and better protect U.S. intellectual property rights. The sides could sign an outline of the deal as early as Dec. 13.\\n\\nThe agreement stands to immediately limit the collateral damage to U.S. importers
column20: who have borne significant costs from the tariffs
column21: and U.S. consumers facing the prospect of much higher prices for consumer goods like mobile phones
column22: laptops
column23: toys and clothing. If finalized
column24: the agreement also would aid the Chinese economy
column25: which is growing at its slowest pace in nearly three decades
column26: giving Beijing more breathing room to address some of its economy's structural risks.\\n\\nAnd there's good news for the global economy
column27: too
column28: as the deal could spur growth by as much as 0.5 percent in 2020. In terms of third countries
column29: the trade deal would give a significant reprieve to key Asian exporters like Singapore
column30: South Korea and Japan
column31: which have experienced major supply chain disruptions and found themselves caught in the crossfire of tariff salvos. But the possible significant increase in U.S. farm purchases could also limit Chinese demand from other suppliers
column32: especially for soybeans from Brazil and Argentina.\\n\\nWhat to Watch For\\n\\nBut now that Washington and Beijing have apparently struck their deal
column33: there are two key points to watch. First
column34: not all the details have been spelled out
column35: meaning clashes over the final wording could yet erupt. The deal's scope regarding intellectual property rights
column36: for instance
column37: will depend on the exact language of the final agreement
column38: and any differences over the farm purchase promise could raise further questions.\\n\\nSecond
column39: there is little guarantee that the United States and China will take a similar view on implementing and interpreting the deal \\u2014 even on the sections that both have already signed off on. In past negotiations
column40: they have differed on the sequencing
column41: timing and details of other deals. Such differences of opinion will almost certainly occur with the phase one deal as well
column42: especially on issues like the contract structures for China to buy U.S. goods
column43: when those purchases will occur
column44: and so forth. Further complicating the picture is a disagreement over human rights issues
column45: which has loomed large over the talks. Given that
column46: it is entirely possible that some of these issues could scuttle this limited deal before the sides manage to hammer out a more wide-ranging agreement.\\n\\nStill
column48: it could rescue the countries' trade talks from endless cycles of tariff escalation and de-escalation that have marred their dialogue in 2018 and 2019. As it is
column49: however
column50: Washington and Beijing are unlikely to seal a more comprehensive deal in 2020 as they have yet to even begin discussing the elephants in the room
column51: such as Chinese industrial policy and Bejing's subsidies to state-owned sectors. What's more
column52: even as the White House phases out tariff options
column53: the bipartisan consensus to curb China's technological capabilities ensures it is all but certain that the United States will continue to oppose Chinese tech firms \\u2014 irrespective of any trade deal or who the president is.\\n\\nFinally
column55: as well as progress this week on the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA)
column56: illustrates Trump's desire to prove his bona fides as a dealmaker ahead of U.S. presidential elections next year. In both cases
column57: the White House made significant concessions on some of its key initial demands to close the deal. On the USMCA
column58: congressional Democrats were able to get much of what they had demanded during the ratification process; in the phase one deal
column59: China floated many of the same concessions it had offered in failed 2017 negotiations. Given Trump's desire for deals
column60: then
column61: he could well rush ahead to end other pressing international disputes in 2020 \\u2014 such as those with North Korea and Iran. But even if Trump is pushing for photo-friendly deals ahead of the presidential elections
column62: Washington and Beijing remain too far apart on structural issues to move an expanded deal forward anytime soon.\\n\\nA Narrow Deal Calms the U.S.-China Trade War

column64: a geopolitical intelligence and advisory firm.\"

column8: \"content\": \"In the final days of 2019
column9: Xia Qingqing joined her parents for a late-night dinner just 200 metres away from the now-notorious South China seafood market
column10: in the central Chinese city of Wuhan.\\n\\nIt has since been identified as the source of the new coronavirus that has infected more than 1
column11: 400 people worldwide
column12: killed more than 40 and plunged China into chaos. Just as hundreds of millions of people should be reuniting with their families to celebrate the biggest holiday of the year
column13: the lunar new year
column14: swathes of the country have been put on lockdown and celebrations all but called off.\\n\\nAs Xia and her parents tucked into a special winter rice and egg porridge on 27 December
column15: even city authorities may not have known that the virus had started spreading around the city.\\n\\nIt was not until three days later that they put out a public warning about a \\u201cpneumonia of unknown cause\\u201d which doctors had identified in Wuhan
column16: and four days later that national authorities filed their first report about the outbreak with the World Health Organisation.\\n\\nIn early January
column17: 36-year-old Xia started running a low fever. By then
column18: authorities had closed the seafood market for disinfection
column19: and identified 44 patients with the unknown pneumonia.\\n\\nBut when she went to a local hospital on 4 January for a check-up
column20: no one asked Xia about possible links to the market
column21: or mentioned the mystery new illness. Doctors told her to go home
column22: rest and take over-the-counter medication.\\n\\nShe followed their advice but her condition continued to worsen. Her fever intensified
column23: she started having respiratory problems
column24: and eating or drinking became painful.\\n\\nHer illness was developing in tandem with knowledge about the mysterious new outbreak. On 9 January
column25: China announced it had identified a new coronavirus
column26: from the same family that caused the 2002 Sars outbreak
column27: in one of the Wuhan patients. Like all viruses in the corona family

column7: \"title\": \"Former Deputies Find Cult Following in True Crime Podcast\"
column8: \"content\": \"Woody Overton and Jim Rathmann started the Real Life Real Crime podcast last year. Each show opens with a reading of the Miranda rights
column9: and what follows are details from crime scenes themselves and information learned directly from perpetrators and victims. The pair have decades of law enforcement experience in Louisiana.\\n\\n\\u201cI don\\u2019t think we ever expected it to get that big. We just didn\\u2019t know
column10: \\u201d Rathmann said. \\u201cPodcasts weren\\u2019t something we knew much about but
column11: once it caught on
column12: we loved it too.\\u201d\\n\\nNeither Rathmann nor Overton works in law enforcement directly anymore
column13: and though they do consulting and provide expert testimony in the law enforcement field
column14: they\\u2019re not bound by any law enforcement protocols when they discuss or analyze the cases they present on each episode.\\n\\n\\u201cWhen I was a detective I could be working an armed robbery and have 15 other cases coming across my desk that day
column15: \\u201d Rathmann said. \\u201cYou may be fielding calls for a burglary a month ago while you\\u2019re telling a family about their homicide case
column16: whereas here we can really focus on one case and pick and choose what we work on.\\u201d\\n\\nWhile Overton still lives in Louisiana
column17: Rathmann is based in Orlando
column18: Florida
column19: making the podcasting schedule and technical elements sometimes difficult. There can be lags or poor audio quality neither has the expertise to deal with
column20: but at times fans have sent in tips on how to improve the sound and suggest tweaks they could make in production.\\n\\nThey both see the loyal and strong fandom as one that is almost part of the production itself
column21: and in some ways it has been.\\n\\nThough many of the episodes surround Livingston Parish crimes Overton and Rathmann worked themselves
column22: last fall they took a deep dive into the case of Courtney Coco \\u2014 a 19-year-old from Alexandria who was last seen in Louisiana on a night in 2004 with friends but was found dead in an abandoned building near Houston days later. The case was worked by Louisiana and Texas authorities.\\n\\n\\u201cTips from the fans spread like wildfire and we had hundreds and hundreds of them
column23: \\u201d Overton said. \\u201cI think for almost seven weeks straight that\\u2019s all Jim and I did was follow those and we solved it
column24: and it was by using the fans.\\u201d\\n\\nAn Alexandria Police Department spokesman did not directly confirm last week whether the agency had received case files from Rathmann and Overton
column25: but said investigators were aware of the podcast and have been following up on the case with the Rapides Parish DA\\u2019s Office.\\n\\n\\u201cIt can be emotionally draining but that\\u2019s okay because you\\u2019ve got to put everything you\\u2019ve got into it
column26: \\u201d Rathmann said. \\u201cThe reason Woody and I work so well is Woody is great at going out and talking with someone and getting information whereas I\\u2019m good at taking the files and reading them one side to the other. Every time a new tip comes in you get excited because this could be the one tip that\\u2019s going to solve the case for you.\\u201d\\n\\nAnother
column27: larger
column28: event is set for Feb. 15 at The Basin Music Hall in Baton Rouge. Both events will be formatted like a podcast episode
column29: talking about a case they haven\\u2019t yet detailed in Real Life Real Crime
column30: with questions and input from audience members.\\n\\nThey hope that if the podcast\\u2019s success keeps growing they can take it on fulltime
column31: and will have the freedom to travel and work cases from the growing list of requests they\\u2019ve received from across the country.\\n\\n\\u201cWe\\u2019re growing almost 100 people a day on some days (in the Facebook group)
column32: \\u201d Overton said. \\u201cThe true crime fans are fanatics. I mean I didn\\u2019t know there was that big of a base for it because evidently nobody else out there is doing what we do
column33: but we love it.\\u201d\"

column7: \"title\": \"'We've had the outdoors ripped from us': What the growing trend of nature memoirs tells us about the state of the world\"
column8: \"content\": \"There\\u2019s a crucial bond we\\u2019ve been severed from
column9: \\u201d says journalist and nature writer Lucy Jones. As humanity has industrialised
column10: commodified
column11: gentrified and all-but destroyed the natural world \\u2013 as we have shut ourselves off from it in cars and offices and flats \\u2013 we have simultaneously found ourselves craving it. \\u201cThe civilising process which imperils wild nature
column12: \\u201d says the environmental historian Roderick Nash
column13: as quoted in Jones\\u2019s galvanising new book Losing Eden
column14: \\u201cis precisely that which creates the need for it\\u201d. Or
column15: as Joni Mitchell would put it
column16: we\\u2019ve paved paradise and put up a parking lot. And we want it back.\\n\\nMaybe that\\u2019s why there\\u2019s such an abundance of nature memoirs at the moment. Alice Vincent\\u2019s Rootbound
column17: which comes out later this month
column18: is a deeply personal exploration of the healing power of plants. Luke Turner\\u2019s Out of the Woods notes the link \\u2013 both literal and metaphorical \\u2013 between the forest and his own sexuality. Elizabeth Jane Burnett\\u2019s The Grassling is a document on grief; the wildlife of Devon connects her to her dying father
column19: while the Swahili words she often uses to talk about it connect her to her mother.\\n\\nIn The Outrun
column20: meanwhile
column21: Amy Liptrot restokes her relationship with nature as she battles with sobriety. Zakiya Mckenzie is one of the first writers in residence for the Forestry Commission. Jessica Lee\\u2019s The Willowherb Review focuses on new nature writing by emerging and established writers of colour. And in Losing Eden
column22: Jones delves deep to try to understand her \\u201cpsychological need for the natural world\\u201d
column23: and wonders what our current \\u201cbiological annihilation\\u201d will do to the mind and spirit of her infant daughter.\\n\\n\\u201cIt\\u2019s a genre people find it really easy to be sniffy about
column24: \\u201d says Vincent of nature writing. Her book
column25: which begins with the sudden and painful end of a long-term relationship
column26: reacts to plants from a storytelling
column27: historical and social point of view
column28: rather than a particularly scientific one. She accepts that some people may view Rootbound as
column29: \\u201csnowflake millennial is sad and discovers plants\\u201d
column30: but believes that the stereotype hides a truth \\u2013 that \\u201cwe\\u2019re hungry for something\\u201d. We are clamouring for the outdoors
column31: she says
column32: \\u201cbecause we\\u2019ve pretty much had it ripped from us as a generation\\u201d.\\n\\nOf course
column33: people have been writing about nature
column34: and its relationship with the human condition
column35: for centuries \\u2013 look at the Romantic poets \\u2013 but it\\u2019s only recently that they are doing so in the context of a capitalism-fuelled climate crisis
column36: and in a world that has shackled itself to technology.\\n\\n\\u201cI think we\\u2019ve been sleepwalking into a place where we think we\\u2019re separate from the rest of nature
column37: \\u201d says Jones
column38: \\u201cand that we can live the way we do without truly thinking about what that means.\\u201d Where Vincent\\u2019s book has at its heart a smaller
column39: more domestic kind of nature \\u2013 namely her garden balcony

column8: \"content\": \"Key Point: The .38 Special pops up again and again.\\n\\nThe .38 Special is one of the most durable cartridges in history. Introduced in 1898 as the .38 Smith & Wesson Special
column9: it was meant to upgrade the U.S. Army\\u2019s firepower. The Army\\u2019s .38 Long Colt cartridge proved mediocre at stopping Philippine insurgents in close-quarters combat\\u2014the .38 Special was one proposed remedy.\\n\\nAlthough the Army eventually chose a different caliber (the .45 ACP)
column10: .38 Special eventually became one of the most popular cartridges in America. The .38 Special became popular with police in the Depression era
column11: when a heavier round that could penetrate the car bodies of motorized bandits was needed. The round was soft-shooting and easy to train police recruits on. The round reigned supreme among law enforcement until the 1970s and 1980s
column12: when 9mm high-capacity semi-automatic handguns became popular.\\n\\nToday
column13: the .38 Special is still popular
column14: particularly among those who prefer the simplicity and aesthetic of revolvers. It is inexpensive and available in a wide variety of configurations
column15: from regular ball ammo to hollow points to high pressure +P rounds. Here are five of the best guns you can shoot .38 Special out of.\\n\\nIntroduced in the early 1990s
column16: the Ruger SP101 was the company\\u2019s dominant .38 Special\\u2013only platform for decades. The SP101 was similar to the larger GP100
column17: but with a shorter barrel and more compact frame. The SP101 has a 2.25-inch barrel
column18: slightly longer than many concealed carry barrels
column19: and features a five-round cylinder. The revolver itself has a stainless steel frame with a satin finish. The SP101 was Ruger\\u2019s concealed carry handgun until the arrival in the mid-2000s of the Ruger LCR.\\n\\nColt\\u2019s Manufacturing Company
column20: founded by Samuel Colt in 1855
column21: was responsible for a great deal of the innovation in revolvers over the past three centuries. The company stepped back from double-action revolvers in the early twenty-first century but in 2017 relaunched its revolver line with the Colt Cobra. The Cobra uses the same name as an older line of Cobra revolvers; both are snub-nosed and meant for concealed carry. The stainless steel revolver features a two-inch barrel

column8: \"content\": \"Key Point: The .38 Special pops up again and again.\\n\\nThe .38 Special is one of the most durable cartridges in history. Introduced in 1898 as the .38 Smith & Wesson Special
column9: it was meant to upgrade the U.S. Army\\u2019s firepower. The Army\\u2019s .38 Long Colt cartridge proved mediocre at stopping Philippine insurgents in close-quarters combat\\u2014the .38 Special was one proposed remedy.\\n\\nAlthough the Army eventually chose a different caliber (the .45 ACP)
column10: .38 Special eventually became one of the most popular cartridges in America. The .38 Special became popular with police in the Depression era
column11: when a heavier round that could penetrate the car bodies of motorized bandits was needed. The round was soft-shooting and easy to train police recruits on. The round reigned supreme among law enforcement until the 1970s and 1980s
column12: when 9mm high-capacity semi-automatic handguns became popular.\\n\\nToday
column13: the .38 Special is still popular
column14: particularly among those who prefer the simplicity and aesthetic of revolvers. It is inexpensive and available in a wide variety of configurations
column15: from regular ball ammo to hollow points to high pressure +P rounds. Here are five of the best guns you can shoot .38 Special out of.\\n\\nIntroduced in the early 1990s
column16: the Ruger SP101 was the company\\u2019s dominant .38 Special\\u2013only platform for decades. The SP101 was similar to the larger GP100
column17: but with a shorter barrel and more compact frame. The SP101 has a 2.25-inch barrel
column18: slightly longer than many concealed carry barrels
column19: and features a five-round cylinder. The revolver itself has a stainless steel frame with a satin finish. The SP101 was Ruger\\u2019s concealed carry handgun until the arrival in the mid-2000s of the Ruger LCR.\\n\\nColt\\u2019s Manufacturing Company
column20: founded by Samuel Colt in 1855
column21: was responsible for a great deal of the innovation in revolvers over the past three centuries. The company stepped back from double-action revolvers in the early twenty-first century but in 2017 relaunched its revolver line with the Colt Cobra. The Cobra uses the same name as an older line of Cobra revolvers; both are snub-nosed and meant for concealed carry. The stainless steel revolver features a two-inch barrel
column22: adjustable sights
column23: a Hogue rubber grip and is rated for powerful +P ammunition. Unlike many concealed carry revolvers\\u2014which hold five rounds\\u2014the Cobra has a six-round cylinder.\\n\\nDescribed as the \\u201cGlock of the (Postwar) Law Enforcement World
column24: \\u201d the Model 10 was the most popular .38 Special revolver of its time. The revolver was originally known as the Smith & Wesson Model 38 Hand Ejector
column25: but was renamed the Model 10 in 1957. It was one of the first revolvers with a cylinder that swung out when a latch on the frame was depressed. This made reloading much faster than using a traditional loading gate. The Model 10 was very popular with law enforcement agencies
column26: and 500

column29: intended for concealed carry. The 442 has an overall length of just 6.3 inches and weighs 14.7 ounces unloaded\\u2014in large part to its aluminum alloy frame. Smith & Wesson still uses steel where it counts: the barrel is made of stainless steel and the cylinder of carbon steel. The 442 is \\u201chammerless

column16: first quarter GDP growth could fall below the 6%
column17: the Chinese government's target.\\n\\n\\\"Without doubt
column18: the hit would be most significant on domestic consumption and tourism-related sectors across the nation

column20: compared with our current forecast of 8%. Given the increased weight of consumption in the economy
column21: the drag on overall growth from such a consumption shock would be more significant than in 2003
column22: all other things being equal.\\\"\\n\\nAs Yao and Lam pointed out
column23: the Chinese economy has changed significantly since the country last experienced a major outbreak. It's bigger
column24: more consumption driven
column25: and way more laden with debt.\\n\\nThe policy guidelines laid down last month at China's 2019 Central Economic Work Conference articulated how China planned to move the country forward under those conditions
column26: while maintain the delicate balance I mentioned before.\\n\\nThe plan was to keep credit flowing
column27: but to make conditions especially easy for private business and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). column28: policymakers also committed themselves to stressing that buying property was not for speculation.\\n\\nThat plan
column29: combined with improvement in industrial and manufacturing sectors due to the end of the trade war

column31: an important manufacturing hub in China that represents 4% of the country's GDP. Putting the region on lockdown will likely slow industrial production
column32: which had just bounced back to 6.9% in December from 6.2% in November.\\n\\nThe longer this virus spreads the more policymakers may feel compelled to ease credit conditions across the board

column35: these things happen to even the best laid plans.\"

column10: \"content\": \"Authored by Robert Bridge via The Strategic Culture Foundation:\\n\\nOnce again
column11: the mainstream media is pushing the repugnant race card
column12: suggesting that Trump supporters are a bunch of knuckle-dragging xenophobes whose only reason for wanting a wall on the Mexican border is because they suffer an aversion to people with different skin color than them.\\n\\nWhat exactly do White Americans \\u2013 who opened the floodgates to immigration in 1965 \\u2013 need to do these days to prove they are not natural born racists? Cancel their monthly subscription to Town and Country? Stop walking their dogs
column13: which are
column14: of course
column15: four-legged vehicles of \\u201cracial segregation
column16: \\u201d or stop attending their evening yoga class
column17: the unsuspecting breeding grounds for white supremacists? Somehow I suspect that even if White people took to burning effigies of Ku Klux Klan members on their manicured front lawns that would not even put a stop to the ugly rumors. Let\\u2019s just face it
column18: the only thing that will finally stop the slanderous slurs is if all White Americans publicly denounce their support of the biggest race-hater of them all
column19: Donald J. Trump. And should they refuse the itinerant Liberal Inquisition will be only too happy to do it for them.\\n\\nJust ask Noah Berlatsky
column20: occasional columnist for MSNBC
column21: whose latest piece was crowned with the zinger of a headline
column22: \\u2018Trump voters motivated by racism may be violating the Constitution. Can they be stopped?\\u2019 Nice leading question there
column23: but the premise that precedes it
column24: that Trump voters are \\u201cmotivated by racism
column25: \\u201d is just one more election-season deceit.\\n\\nBerlatsky\\u2019s article opens with the conclusion that Donald Trump \\u201cran an openly racist campaign for president
column26: \\u201d and that his popular rallying slogan \\u201cMake America Great Again\\u201d is actually code that can be translated into \\u201cAmerica was greater when white people\\u2019s power was more sweeping and more secure.\\u201d Yet nowhere in any of Trump\\u2019s numerous campaign utterances or even Tweets has he ever singled out America\\u2019s White population as the intended sole beneficiary of his plans to remake the U.S. economy. In fact
column27: just the opposite. As Trump has made it his goal to return some of the shine to America\\u2019s industrial Rustbelt
column28: threatening companies with penalties and public scorn if they relocate their production operations overseas
column29: the unemployment rate among Blacks now stands at 5.9%
column30: down from 7.5% at the start of his presidency. At the same time
column31: the employment rate among Hispanics is at historic highs.\\n\\nAt this point
column32: the Democrats will invariably mention Trump\\u2019s promise to build a wall on the U.S.-Mexican border
column33: a promise that arguably won the real estate developer the White House in 2016. Yet Trump
column34: the Democrats argue
column35: is an unrepentant racist because he admitted to an unsavory truth that even Hispanics living in America agree with: \\u201cWhen Mexico sends its people
column36: they\\u2019re not sending their best\\u2026They\\u2019re sending people that have lots of problems
column37: and they\\u2019re bringing those problems with us. They\\u2019re bringing drugs. They\\u2019re bringing crime. They\\u2019re rapists. And some
column38: I assume
column39: are good people.\\u201d\\n\\nTrump was not arguing
column40: of course
column41: that all Mexicans are rapists or criminals. He was arguing that of the many who do make it across the border a disproportionate number do fit the description.\\n\\nAt this point
column42: it needs to be asked why the Democrats deign to show so much care and compassion for those illegals breaching America\\u2019s border on a daily basis
column43: at the very same time Democratic strongholds
column44: like California and New York
column45: are already bursting at the seams with tent cities and grinding poverty. Suffice it to consider a comment by a British tourist to San Francisco
column46: the one-time crown gem of the increasingly tarnished
column47: Democratic-controlled Golden State: \\u201cI can\\u2019t understand how anyone can live in a place where their everyday trip to get groceries or go to work includes a multitude of beggars asking for spare change or a meal.\\u201d\\n\\nConsidering that the Democrats can\\u2019t even take care of their own burgeoning problems in their primary constituencies
column48: what is the real motivation behind their proposals to open the U.S. border and abolish U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE)? After all
column49: these are the very same people who screamed \\u2018not in my backyard!\\u2019 when Trump threatened to send all apprehended illegals to the so-called \\u2018sanctuary cities\\u2019. Nancy Pelosi skirted the periphery of racism when she called the idea \\u201cdisrespectful.\\u201d\\n\\nWould their sham benevolence have anything to do with securing more Democratic voters
column50: or guaranteeing that the Republican Party eventually goes the way of the dinosaurs? Was New York Governor Andrew Cuomo motivated by pure compassion when he signed legislation granting driver\\u2019s licenses to illegal immigrants
column51: who may now cast a \\u2018legal\\u2019 vote under New York\\u2019s notoriously loose voting laws? Now Democrats are demanding the elimination Voter ID rules
column52: declaring them racist against minorities. This is one of the ways Berlatsky proposes to end so-called \\u201cracist voting\\u201d now purportedly contaminating U.S. politics.\\n\\nIt\\u2019s no secret that Hispanic Americans traditionally vote Democratic
column53: and if that tendency were to change tomorrow you can bet that Chuck Schumer and Nancy Pelosi would be camped out daily at the Mexican border
column54: demanding the necessary funds to finish the project.\\n\\nIn the final analysis
column55: the Democrat\\u2019s groundless assertion that Trump supporters are kneejerk racists disintegrates when it is remembered that up to 10 million former Obama supporters \\u2013 many of them White \\u2013 switched allegiances to the Trump camp in the 2016 presidential election. Are we really expected to believe that all of those Americans suddenly became hardcore racists with the arrival of the evil \\u2018orange man\\u2019 and his pledge to build a wall? That sounds highly unlikely. The far more logical explanation for this massive change in political sentiment is that Trump\\u2019s plan to remedy America\\u2019s dangerously porous borders
column56: thereby enhancing the security of all Americans
column57: regardless of skin color
column58: was a welcomed idea across the board.\\n\\nNevertheless
column59: the real danger is that the Democrats
column60: entranced by the cult of political correctness and an out-of-control cancel culture
column61: will attempt by some extreme measures to identify and ban so-called \\u2018racist Trump supporters\\u2019 who are just regular Americans looking for a leader who will provide them with a well-guarded country that protects the rights of all its citizens regardless of skin color. Banning undesirable Trump voters from the ballet box may eventually become as easy as censoring right-leaning Twitter users.\\n\\nClearly
column62: the Democrats learned absolutely nothing from the mistake of branding Trump supports \\u201cdeplorables\\u201d \\u2013 to quote Hillary Clinton \\u2013 and have only worsened their present position by calling these same voters
column63: many of them former Obama supporters
column64: \\u201cracist.\\u201d Such a gross simplification and misunderstanding of the current American political realities goes far at explaining why the Democrats stand very little chance of beating Trump at the ballot box.\"

column7: \"title\": \"Little known tale reveals West Lothian bing was chosen as spot for nuclear bunker in event of an attack\"
column8: \"content\": \"The Courier have teamed up with our friends at Almond Valley Heritage Trust to bring our readers stories from West Lothian\\u2019s past.\\n\\nThis week
column9: we bring you the story of the Bing
column10: waiting for the bomb.\\n\\nFrom the top of Hermand Oil Works bing you can enjoy a panoramic view across the Firth of Forth to the green fields of Fife
column11: past the Bathgate and Ochil hills
column12: and beyond to the Highlands of Perthshire.\\n\\nIn the event of a nuclear attack
column13: the site might provide a grandstand view of the destruction of Scotland\\u2019s capital
column14: the conflagration of Grangemouth
column15: and mushroom clouds on the western skyline marking the end of industrial Lanarkshire.\\n\\nIt is with prospect in mind that the bing was chosen
column17: as site for construction of a Royal Observer Corps monitoring post.\\n\\nThe Royal Observer Corps was a volunteer organisation formed in 1925 to serve as \\u201cthe ears and eyes of the Air Force\\u201d.\\n\\nDuring the Second World War they played a vital role in reporting enemy aircraft movements
column18: but in a subsequent age of radar and high altitude jets
column19: they could make little useful contribution to defence and plans were drawn up to disband the organisation.\\n\\nHowever
column20: with the growing prospect of nuclear conflict
column21: a new role was found for the Corps. Rather than spotting aircraft
column22: they were tasked with front-line reporting in the event of a nuclear strike.\\n\\nFrom 1956 a network of almost 1500 underground monitoring posts were built throughout the length and breadth of Britain. West Lothian received only three posts; the West Calder ROC post on top of Hermand bing
column23: close to the West Calder to Harburn road; the Bathgate ROC post near Crosshill Drive and the Bo\\u2019ness ROC post near the clubhouse of the West Lothian Golf Club.\\n\\nThese were all part of the ROC No.24 group
column24: whose headquarters were in a bunker beneath RAF Turnhouse.\\n\\nEach monitoring post consisted of a small room within a reinforced concrete box
column25: covered by at least three feet of soil and accessed through a manhole and a 19ft long vertical steel ladder.\\n\\nThis was intended to provide some protection against a nuclear blast and reduce exposure to radiation.\\n\\nLittle showed above the surface other than filter equipment to cleanse incoming air and various pieces of monitoring equipment. At times of threat
column26: the posts were manned by part-time volunteers of the ROC
column27: who were issued with a uniform and paid a nominal fee for the time spent at their post.\\n\\nRecruitment advertisements portrayed membership of the corps as suitable for \\u201cmen and women between the ages of 16 and 60 who are looking for an interesting
column28: worthwhile hobby\\u201d.\\n\\nEach post was equipped with bunk beds
column29: a chemical toilet and had ration packs \\u201ccontaining biscuits. steak and kidney pudding
column30: tea
column31: sugar
column32: milk
column33: etc. which would sustain three men without contact with the outside world for three days.\\u201d\\n\\nIn the event of a nuclear attack
column34: the monitoring post would report levels of radiation
column35: other measurements
column36: and readings from the \\u201cground zero indicator\\u201d.\\n\\nThis was little more than a drum lined with photographic paper which some poor soul would need to emerge from the bunker to retrieve.\\n\\nWhen developed
column37: this provided an indication of the intensity and direction of the blast.\\n\\nWe should be eternally thankful that none of these systems and contingency plans were ever tested in anger. Following the fall of Berlin Wall and the removal of the Soviet threat
column38: the ROC were disbanded in 1991.\\n\\nToday many ROC observation posts survive locked and forgotten in remote parts of the country.\\n\\nThe West Calder post was abandoned in 1991
column39: and in 2005 it was still possible to climb down into the bunker and survey a scatter of papers and furniture
column40: while a portrait of Her Majesty the Queen smiled calmly down from the wall.\\n\\nSince then
column41: much of the spent shale has been quarried away
column42: and for a number of years the exposed sides of the concrete room hung perilously at the edge of the bing.\\n\\nThe concrete box now sits
column43: almost upside down
column44: at the foot of the bing; a monument to a horror which thankfully never arrived.\"

column8: \"content\": \"ANTHONY WATSON sat down with a GOAT after England's heartbreaking World Cup defeat to the Springboks.\\n\\nAnd the once-in-a-lifetime meeting with the NFL's greatest of all time - triple Super Bowl hero Jerry Rice - has fired-up the England star ahead of this year's Six Nations.\\n\\nLegendary San Francisco 49ers wide receiver Rice holds more than 100 NFL records and scored 208 touchdowns - a stat that is unlikely to ever be broken.\\n\\nBut it was Rice's story of relentless dedication that has winger Watson buzzing ahead of England's Championship opener in Paris a week today.\\n\\nWatson said: \\\"Meeting Jerry Rice was incredible and a few of the stories he told me will stay with me forever.\\n\\n\\\"This is guy who sawed off his own cast on his leg just 11 weeks after doing his ACL. . . he then played a week later
column9: ran 150 yards and scored two touchdowns.\\n\\n\\\"I know it's probably not the smartest thing to do and he admitted that!\\n\\n\\\"But it just goes to show the level of commitment he had to winning and playing. So I wanted to talk to him about a few of the stories I had heard about him.\\n\\n\\\"Kyle Sinckler said that one year after Jerry won the Super Bowl with the 49ers their quarter-back was traded to another team.\\n\\n\\\"This guy goes back to the club to collect all his stuff and there was Jerry Rice catching balls. . . with the groundsman!\\n\\n\\\"Everyone else was probably off partying. So the commitment that he had was incredible and there was no surprise that he won so much in the game.\\\"\\n\\nWatson
column10: just 26 next month has already won two Six Nations - including the 2016 Grand Slam.\\n\\nAnd he is showing the same level of devotion to get ready for his sixth Championships as his American idol Rice.\\n\\nAfter last year's World Cup defeat to South Africa Watson wasn't going to stew and develop a Japan hangover heading into 2020.\\n\\nHe said: \\\"We landed back form the World Cup on the Tuesday

column12: met the coaches

column14: either.\\n\\nHe said: \\\"I'm not too concerned about trying to serve up redemption or anything like that.\\n\\n\\\"I was very happy to be part of that World Cup squad

So I wanted to talk to him about a few of the stories I had heard about him.\\n\\n\\\"Kyle Sinckler said that one year after Jerry won the Super Bowl with the 49ers their quarter-back was traded to another team.\\n\\n\\\"This guy goes back to the club to collect all his stuff and there was Jerry Rice catching balls. . . with the groundsman!\\n\\n\\\"Everyone else was probably off partying. So the commitment that he had was incredible and there was no surprise that he won so much in the game.\\\"\\n\\nWatson
column10: just 26 next month has already won two Six Nations - including the 2016 Grand Slam.\\n\\nAnd he is showing the same level of devotion to get ready for his sixth Championships as his American idol Rice.\\n\\nAfter last year's World Cup defeat to South Africa Watson wasn't going to stew and develop a Japan hangover heading into 2020.\\n\\nHe said: \\\"We landed back form the World Cup on the Tuesday
column11: I went into the club on the Wednesday
column12: met the coaches
column13: had about eight days off then I started getting frustrated.\\n\\n\\\"The level of fitness you get to when you are away with England is what helps you perform like an international when you go back to your club.\\n\\n\\\"So I didn't want to let that all go to waste.\\\"\\n\\nBut the Bath ace isn't on any kind of revenge mission this Six Nations
column14: either.\\n\\nHe said: \\\"I'm not too concerned about trying to serve up redemption or anything like that.\\n\\n\\\"I was very happy to be part of that World Cup squad
column15: but I wanted to be part of a squad that did something special in Japan.\\n\\n\\\"So when you fail to do that on the pitch
column16: it is disappointing - and I don't think that will ever change for us.\\n\\n\\\"I don't think I will ever be buzzing about the fact that we got to the World Cup final because of the result.\\n\\n\\\"But in terms of the feeling we had - being together for such a long time - I think we all really enjoyed it and the journey that we went on.\\\"\\n\\nWatson even plans to bring a touch of Japan to his Somerset pad.\\n\\nBecause during his time in the orient
column17: Watson became a Bath boy in more ways than one.\\n\\nAlong with teammates Sinckler and Willi Heinz
column18: the trio would take daily trips to the Japanese naked baths - or onsens.\\n\\nAnd his love-affair for the boiling hot tubs continues as he has grand designs to build two giant baths in his back garden - a hot one that will be about 45 degrees and a cold one at around 6 degrees.\\n\\nWatson
column19: a Land Rover ambassador
column20: added: \\\"I have never used anything as good to help me recover.\\n\\n\\\"It's not going to be exactly like the onsens we had in Japan
column21: but I have a guy coming to check that my terrace can support them.\\n\\n\\\"I don't know the science behind it or how it works
column22: but I just know my body felt five times better after an onsen.\\n\\n\\\"Myself
column23: Sincks and Willi Heinz probably spent more than an hour in them every day - rotating between the hot and cold ones.\\n\\n\\\"We would talk about everything - from rugby
column24: to our families and any old rubbish.\\n\\n\\\"I didn't know Willi before the World Cup either and I didn't expect to build up such a special relationship with him either.\\n\\n\\\"I don't think my missus will use them at home
column25: but I know the heating bills will be totally worth it.\\n\\n\\\"And when I get them done
column26: Kyle and Willi can come round whenever they want
column27: I would love that.\\\"\\n\\nWatson also might well be called upon as the England full-back for the Six Nations.\\n\\nHe was being put through his paces yesterday by coach Neil Craig in training out in Portugal - catching high balls and passing off his left hand.\\n\\nBut bad news for England yesterday came with Joe Launchbury being ruled out of their Six Nations opener.\\n\\nThe Wasps second-row has a knee injury and will not be fit until their second game away to Scotland.\\n\\nAnthony Watson is a Land Rover ambassador. column15: but I wanted to be part of a squad that did something special in Japan.\\n\\n\\\"So when you fail to do that on the pitch
column16: it is disappointing - and I don't think that will ever change for us.\\n\\n\\\"I don't think I will ever be buzzing about the fact that we got to the World Cup final because of the result.\\n\\n\\\"But in terms of the feeling we had - being together for such a long time - I think we all really enjoyed it and the journey that we went on.\\\"\\n\\nWatson even plans to bring a touch of Japan to his Somerset pad.\\n\\nBecause during his time in the orient
column17: Watson became a Bath boy in more ways than one.\\n\\nAlong with teammates Sinckler and Willi Heinz
column18: the trio would take daily trips to the Japanese naked baths - or onsens.\\n\\nAnd his love-affair for the boiling hot tubs continues as he has grand designs to build two giant baths in his back garden - a hot one that will be about 45 degrees and a cold one at around 6 degrees.\\n\\nWatson
column19: a Land Rover ambassador
column20: added: \\\"I have never used anything as good to help me recover.\\n\\n\\\"It's not going to be exactly like the onsens we had in Japan
column21: but I have a guy coming to check that my terrace can support them.\\n\\n\\\"I don't know the science behind it or how it works
column22: but I just know my body felt five times better after an onsen.\\n\\n\\\"Myself
column23: Sincks and Willi Heinz probably spent more than an hour in them every day - rotating between the hot and cold ones.\\n\\n\\\"We would talk about everything - from rugby
column24: to our families and any old rubbish.\\n\\n\\\"I didn't know Willi before the World Cup either and I didn't expect to build up such a special relationship with him either.\\n\\n\\\"I don't think my missus will use them at home
column25: but I know the heating bills will be totally worth it.\\n\\n\\\"And when I get them done
column26: Kyle and Willi can come round whenever they want
column27: I would love that.\\\"\\n\\nWatson also might well be called upon as the England full-back for the Six Nations.\\n\\nHe was being put through his paces yesterday by coach Neil Craig in training out in Portugal - catching high balls and passing off his left hand.\\n\\nBut bad news for England yesterday came with Joe Launchbury being ruled out of their Six Nations opener.\\n\\nThe Wasps second-row has a knee injury and will not be fit until their second game away to Scotland.\\n\\nAnthony Watson is a Land Rover ambassador. column8: \"content\": \"This week brought news that atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO\\u2082) levels at the Mauna Loa atmospheric observatory in Hawaii have risen steeply for the seventh year in a row
column9: reaching a May 2019 average of 414.7 parts per million (ppm).\\n\\nIt was the highest monthly average in 61 years of measurements at that observatory
column10: and comes five years after CO\\u2082 concentrations first breached the 400ppm milestone.\\n\\nBut in truth
column11: the amount of greenhouse gas in our atmosphere is higher still. If we factor in the presence of other greenhouse gases besides carbon dioxide
column12: we find that the world has already ticked past yet another milestone: 500ppm of what we call \\u201cCO\\u2082-equivalent\\u201d
column13: or CO\\u2082-e.\\n\\nIn July 2018
column14: the combination of long-lived greenhouse gases measured in the \\u201ccleanest air in the world\\u201d at Cape Grim Baseline Atmospheric Pollution Stationsurpassed 500ppm CO\\u2082-e.\\n\\nAs the atmosphere of the Southern Hemisphere contains less pollution than the north
column15: this means the global average atmospheric concentration of greenhouse gases is now well above this level.\\n\\nAlthough CO\\u2082 is the most abundant greenhouse gas
column16: dozens of other gases \\u2013 including methane (CH\\u2084)
column17: nitrous oxide (N\\u2082O) and the synthetic greenhouse gases \\u2013 also trap heat. Many of them are more powerful greenhouse gases than CO\\u2082
column18: and some linger for longer in the atmosphere. That means they have a significant influence on how much the planet is warming.\\n\\nSouthern Hemispheric radiative forcing relative to 1750 due to the long-lived greenhouse gases (carbon dioxide

column23: from the Cape Grim Air Archive

column28: showing CO\\u2082-e surpassing 500ppm in July 2018. CSIRO\\n\\nThis milestone
column29: like so many others
column30: is symbolic. The difference between 499 and 500ppm CO\\u2082-e is marginal in terms of the fate of the climate and the life it sustains. column31: to avoid the most dangerous effects of climate change. column32: since pre-industrial times
column33: the global climate (including oceans) has warmed by only 0.7\\u2103.\\n\\nThis is partly because industrial smog and other tiny particles (together called aerosols) reflect sunlight out to space
column34: offsetting some of the expected warming. What\\u2019s more
column35: the climate system responds slowly to rising atmospheric greenhouse gas concentrations because much of the excess heat is taken up by the oceans.\\n\\nThe amount of heat each greenhouse gas can trap depends on its absorption spectrum \\u2013 how strongly it can absorb energy at different wavelengths
column36: particularly in the infrared range. Despite its simple molecular structure
column37: there is still much to learn about the heat-absorbing properties of methane
column38: the second-biggest component of CO\\u2082-e.\\n\\nStudies published in 2016 and 2018 led to the estimate of methane\\u2019s warming potential being revised upwards by 15%
column39: meaning methane is now considered to be 32 times more efficient at trapping heat in the atmosphere than CO\\u2082
column40: on a per-molecule basis over a 100-year time span.\\n\\nConsidering this new evidence
column41: we calculate that greenhouse gas concentrations at Cape Grim crossed the 500ppm CO\\u2082-e threshold in July 2018.\\n\\nThis is higher than the official estimate based on the previous formulation for calculating CO\\u2082-e
column42: which remains in widespread use. For instance
column43: the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration is reporting 2018 CO\\u2082-e as 496ppm.\\n\\nThe graph below shows the two curves for the time evolution of CO\\u2082-e in the atmosphere as measured at Cape Grim
column44: using the old and new formulae.\\n\\nCape Grim monthly CO2-e from 2015 until Sept 2018 calculated using the old and new formulae. CSIRO\\n\\nSome greenhouse gases
column45: such as chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs)
column46: also deplete the ozone layer. CFCs are in decline thanks to the Montreal Protocol
column47: which bans the production and use of these chemicals
column48: despite reports that indicate some recent production of CFC-11 in China.\\n\\nBut unfortunately their ozone-safe replacements

column7: \"title\": \"More reactions to my New York Times Op-Ed\"
column8: \"content\": \"Since its publication on Thursday
column9: my New York Times Op-Ed has continued to stimulate dialogue and discussion. It was also published in Saturday's print edition. This post will highlight a few of the responses.\\n\\nFirst
column10: Ross Douthat wrote an op-ed
column11: titled \\\"Trump's Best Defense It's that he wants to be L.B.J.
column12: not Mussolini. (But that's still a problem.)\\\"\\n\\nIn a Times op-ed this week
column13: the Josh Blackman of the South Texas College of Law Houston argued that this narrowing of the impeachment power reflects the difficulty of defining when politicized machinations shade into the abuse of power. Allowing that Trump is particularly crude about it
column14: all presidents conflate their own political self-interest with the national interest \\u2014 and so deciding when a president crosses the line and betrays his office is almost always a task best left up to the voters. column11: titled \\\"Trump's Best Defense It's that he wants to be L.B.J.
column12: not Mussolini. (But that's still a problem.)\\\"\\n\\nIn a Times op-ed this week
column13: the Josh Blackman of the South Texas College of Law Houston argued that this narrowing of the impeachment power reflects the difficulty of defining when politicized machinations shade into the abuse of power. Allowing that Trump is particularly crude about it
column14: all presidents conflate their own political self-interest with the national interest \\u2014 and so deciding when a president crosses the line and betrays his office is almost always a task best left up to the voters. Both the strengths and limits of Blackman's argument are distilled in one of his historical examples: Lyndon Johnson's appointment of Supreme Court Justice Tom C. Clark's son Ramsey Clark as attorney general
column15: part of a maneuver to induce Clark's resignation so that Johnson could then appoint the first African-American justice and consolidate African-American support. This is a useful example because it's been apparent for a while that Trump doesn't want to be an American Mussolini so much as he wants to be a less legislatively minded L.B.J. \\u2014 meaning that his conception of the presidency belongs to the middle of the 20th century
column16: when a casual corruption was more commonplace
column17: and presidents routinely used their powers to spy on political opponents (as L.B.J. did to Barry Goldwater) or undermine them
column18: enable their private appetites (cough
column19: J.F.K.) and cover up their scandals.\\n\\nSecond
column20: Matt Ford wrote an essay for The New Republic
column21: titled \\\"The Best Defense of Donald Trump: A conservative legal scholar presents an exculpation of the president that's worth engaging.\\\"\\n\\nBut in this late hour
column22: an exception has arrived in the form of Josh Blackman
column23: a South Texas College of Law Houston professor. Blackman is a conservative legal scholar who has played a notable role in the legal battles surrounding the Affordable Care Act. column24: \\\" and he disagrees with Trumpworld's constant assertion that impeachment amounts to the overturning of an election. While senators may have no choice but to listen to Trump's lawyers
column25: engaging with the strongest alternatives available is more productive for everyone else.\\n\\nMatt raises a number of important points that I hope to respond to in due course.\\n\\nThird
column26: Jonathan Bernstein wrote an essay for Bloomberg Opinion.\\n\\nWhat of the case made by law professor Josh Blackman in the New York Times on Thursday: that presidents often pursue policies in hopes of improving their political prospects? It is true
column27: of course
column28: that presidents consider domestic politics
column29: including electoral politics
column30: in everything they do. There's nothing wrong with that. Presidents should act to increase their influence
column31: and that includes taking actions with their professional reputation and personal popularity in mind. . . . Blackman's analysis is also wrong because it matters how a president uses policy for political advantage. Trump is accused of soliciting foreign election interference! Unlike maneuvering to get a Supreme Court justice to resign
column32: or even deploying troops
column33: Trump tried to get a foreign nation to influence an election. That's not just a likely violation of U.S. law; it's contrary to his oath to \\\"preserve
column34: protect and defend the Constitution of the United States.\\\"\\n\\nFourth
column35: Laura Ingraham talked about my piece on her Fox News show:\\n\\nFifth
column36: Ben Shapiro discussed my piece on his podcast. (Many
column37: many law students in particular listen to Shapiro.)\\n\\nFinally

column39: as well as his own blog.\\n\\nIn an excellent opinion column in The New York Times

text: this climate change tale comes with a sting there are those who say the climate has always changed and that carbon dioxide levels have always fluctuated
source: {\id\": \"nationalinterest--2020-01-26--This Climate Change Tale Comes With a Sting\"
column7: \"title\": \"This Climate Change Tale Comes With a Sting\"
column8: \"content\": \"There are those who say the climate has always changed
column9: and that carbon dioxide levels have always fluctuated. That\\u2019s true. But it\\u2019s also true that since the industrial revolution
column10: CO\\u2082 levels in the atmosphere have climbed to levels that are unprecedented over hundreds of millennia.\\n\\nSo here\\u2019s a short video we made
column11: to put recent climate change and carbon dioxide emissions into the context of the past 800
column12: 000 years.\\n\\nEarth has a natural greenhouse effect
column13: and it is really important. Without it
column14: the average temperature on the surface of the planet would be about -18\\u2103 and human life would not exist. Carbon dioxide (CO\\u2082) is one of the gases in our atmosphere that traps heat and makes the planet habitable.\\n\\nWe have known about the greenhouse effect for well over a century. About 150 years ago
column15: a physicist called John Tyndall used laboratory experiments to demonstrate the greenhouse properties of CO\\u2082 gas. Then
column16: in the late 1800s
column17: the Swedish chemist Svante Arrhenius first calculated the greenhouse effect of CO\\u2082 in our atmosphere and linked it to past ice ages on our planet.\\n\\nModern scientists and engineers have explored these links in intricate detail in recent decades
column18: by drilling into the ice sheets that cover Antarctica and Greenland. Thousands of years of snow have compressed into thick slabs of ice. The resulting ice cores can be more than 3km long and extend back a staggering 800
column19: 000 years.\\n\\nScientists use the chemistry of the water molecules in the ice layers to see how the temperature has varied through the millennia. These ice layers also trap tiny bubbles from the ancient atmosphere
column20: allowing us to measure prehistoric CO\\u2082 levels directly.\\n\\nThe ice cores reveal an incredibly tight connection between temperature and greenhouse gas levels through the ice age cycles
column21: thus proving the concepts put forward by Arrhenius more than a century ago.\\n\\nIn previous warm periods
column22: it was not a CO\\u2082 spike that kickstarted the warming
column23: but small and predictable wobbles in Earth\\u2019s rotation and orbit around the Sun. CO\\u2082 played a big role as a natural amplifier of the small climate shifts initiated by these wobbles. As the planet began to cool
column24: more CO\\u2082 dissolved into the oceans
column25: reducing the greenhouse effect and causing more cooling. Similarly
column26: CO\\u2082 was released from the oceans to the atmosphere when the planet warmed
column27: driving further warming.\\n\\nBut things are very different this time around. Humans are responsible for adding huge quantities of extra CO\\u2082 to the atmosphere \\u2013 and fast.\\n\\nThe speed at which CO\\u2082 is rising has no comparison in the recorded past. The fastest natural shifts out of ice ages saw CO\\u2082 levels increase by around 35 parts per million (ppm) in 1
column28: 000 years. It might be hard to believe
column29: but humans have emitted the equivalent amount in just the last 17 years.\\n\\nBefore the industrial revolution
column30: the natural level of atmospheric CO\\u2082 during warm interglacials was around 280 ppm. The frigid ice ages
column31: which caused kilometre-thick ice sheets to build up over much of North America and Eurasia
column32: had CO\\u2082 levels of around 180 ppm.\\n\\nBurning fossil fuels
column33: such as coal
column34: oil and gas
column35: takes ancient carbon that was locked within the Earth and puts it into the atmosphere as CO\\u2082. Since the industrial revolution humans have burned an enormous amount of fossil fuel
column36: causing atmospheric CO\\u2082 and other greenhouse gases to skyrocket.\\n\\nIn mid-2017
column37: atmospheric CO\\u2082 now stands at 409 ppm. This is completely unprecedented in the past 800
column38: 000 years.\\n\\nThe massive blast of CO\\u2082 is causing the climate to warm rapidly. The last IPCC report concluded that by the end of this century we will get to more than 4\\u2103 above pre-industrial levels (1850-99) if we continue on a high-emissions pathway.\\n\\nIf we work towards the goals of the Paris Agreement
column39: by rapidly curbing our CO\\u2082 emissions and developing new technologies to remove excess CO\\u2082 from the atmosphere
column40: then we stand a chance of limiting warming to around 2\\u2103.\\n\\nThe fundamental science is very well understood. The evidence that climate change is happening is abundant and clear. The difficult part is: what do we do next? More than ever
column41: we need strong
column42: cooperative and accountable leadership from politicians of all nations. Only then will we avoid the worst of climate change and adapt to the impacts we can\\u2019t halt.\\n\\nThe authors acknowledge the contributions of Wes Mountain (multimedia)
column43: Alicia Egan (editing) and Andrew King (model projection data).\\n\\nBen Henley
column44: Research Fellow in Climate and Water Resources
column45: University of Melbourne
column46: University of Melbourne and Nerilie Abram
column48: Research School of Earth Sciences; Chief Investigator for the ARC Centre of Excellence for Climate Extremes
column49: Australian National University\\n\\nThis article is republished from The Conversation under a Creative Commons license. Read the original article.\"
column51: Nerilie Abram\"
